text: The <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> paradox in the pathogenesis of tumor progression .

Recent evidence suggests that the <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule appears in two different forms : the mutant <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that stimulates tumor progression , and wild type <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that inhibits tumor progression .

In addition , it has been established that <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) can activate the expression of wild type <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in concert with the nuclear transcription factor , NF-kappa B . Both <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and NF-kappa B are also involved in the stimulation of the pathway that leads to the expression of major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class I molecules and , hence , antigen presentation to the T cells .

text: In this paper we shall advance the hypothesis that : ( i ) <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> indirectly controls immune surveillance ; and ( ii ) <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> controls DNA repair and tumor suppression through the regulation of wild type <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
